title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: df <- sim_quasianscombe_set_1()  plot(df) +   xlim(0, NA) +   ylim(0, NA)

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: df3_1 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_3(df)  df3_2 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_3(df, residual_factor = 0)

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: df4_1 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_4(df)  df4_2 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_4(df, rescale_to = c(0, .1), prop = 0.5)

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: df5_1 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df)  df5_2 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = function(x) rev(x**4))

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
text: [@warnes](https://github.com/warnes) gtools package
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(tidyr) library(purrr) library(broom)  dfs <- list(   "Original" = df,   "Set 3 v1" = df3_1,   "Set 3 v2" = df3_2,   "Set 4 v1" = df4_1,   "Set 4 v2" = df4_2,   "Set 5 v1" = df5_1,   "Set 5 v2" = df5_2 )  dfs <- dfs |>    tibble::enframe(name = "set") |>    tidyr::unnest(cols = c(value)) stars.pval <- function(p.value) {   unclass(     symnum(p.value,       corr = FALSE, na = FALSE,       cutpoints = c(0, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 1),       symbols = c("***", "**", "*", ".", " ")     )   ) }

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: ggplot(dfs, aes(x, y)) +   geom_point(shape = 21, fill = "gray80", color = "gray60") +   geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +   facet_wrap(vars(set)) #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'

title: Quasi Anscombe data sets
code: df_mods <- dfs |>    dplyr::group_nest(set) |>    dplyr::mutate(     model = map(data, lm, formula = y ~ x),     parameters = map(model, broom::tidy)     # value = map(model, coefficients),     # coef  = map(value, names)     )   df_mods |>    dplyr::select(set, parameters) |>    tidyr::unnest(cols = c(parameters)) |>    dplyr::mutate(sig = stars.pval(p.value)) #> # A tibble: 14 × 7 #>    set      term        estimate std.error statistic  p.value sig   #>    <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> #>  1 Original (Intercept)    2.93     0.213      13.7  1.41e-24 ***   #>  2 Original x              0.509    0.0427     11.9  9.13e-21 ***   #>  3 Set 3 v1 (Intercept)    2.93     0.324       9.05 1.41e-14 ***   #>  4 Set 3 v1 x              0.509    0.0649      7.85 5.37e-12 ***   #>  5 Set 3 v2 (Intercept)    2.93     0.283      10.3  2.19e-17 ***   #>  6 Set 3 v2 x              0.509    0.0568      8.97 2.07e-14 ***   #>  7 Set 4 v1 (Intercept)    2.93     0.154      19.1  1.01e-34 ***   #>  8 Set 4 v1 x              0.509    0.0275     18.5  1.04e-33 ***   #>  9 Set 4 v2 (Intercept)    2.93     0.198      14.8  1.08e-26 ***   #> 10 Set 4 v2 x              0.509    0.0376     13.5  3.73e-24 ***   #> 11 Set 5 v1 (Intercept)    2.93     0.0837     35.0  3.59e-57 ***   #> 12 Set 5 v1 x              0.509    0.0168     30.3  1.27e-51 ***   #> 13 Set 5 v2 (Intercept)    2.93     0.0822     35.6  6.48e-58 ***   #> 14 Set 5 v2 x              0.509    0.0165     30.9  2.39e-52 ***

what: Tools to simulate data set to teach Statical Models and ML Algorithms
title: Tools to simulate data set to teach Statical Models and ML Algorithms
text: goal klasset …

title: Tools to simulate data set to teach Statical Models and ML Algorithms
text: can install development version klasset GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("jbkunst/klasset")

title: Tools to simulate data set to teach Statical Models and ML Algorithms
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(klasset) ## basic example code

what: Generate data sets to apply a clustering algorithm — sim_clusters
title: Generate data sets to apply a clustering algorithm — sim_clusters
text: Generate data sets apply clustering algorithm

title: Generate data sets to apply a clustering algorithm — sim_clusters
code: sim_clusters(n = 1000, groups = 3, props = NULL, add_group_col = FALSE)

title: Generate data sets to apply a clustering algorithm — sim_clusters
text: n intenger groups integer props vector probabilties length groups. add_group_col logical value.

title: Generate data sets to apply a clustering algorithm — sim_clusters
code: set.seed(123456)  df <- sim_clusters()  plot(df)   set.seed(123456)  df <- sim_clusters(add_group_col = TRUE)  plot(df)

what: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
text: function generate data set Type 1  creating first x random vector apply linear transformation using beta0 beta1 finally adding normal distributed noise using error_sd creating y values.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
code: sim_quasianscombe_set_1(   n = 100,   beta0 = 3,   beta1 = 0.5,   error_sd = 0.5,   x_mean = 5,   x_sd = 1,   x_dist = "norm" )

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
text: n n, default value: 100 beta0 beta0, default value: 3, beta1 beta1, default value: 0.5 error_sd error_sd, default value: 0.1 x_mean x_mean, default value: 5 x_sd x_sd, default value: 1 x_dist x_dist, default value: "norm"

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
text: typical example regression analysis taught.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 1 — sim_quasianscombe_set_1
code: df <- sim_quasianscombe_set_1()  df #> # A tibble: 100 × 2 #>        x     y #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  2.76  4.60 #>  2  2.94  4.25 #>  3  3.05  5.00 #>  4  3.24  3.97 #>  5  3.30  4.04 #>  6  3.36  4.66 #>  7  3.44  4.18 #>  8  3.48  5.29 #>  9  3.53  4.71 #> 10  3.64  4.23 #> # … with 90 more rows  plot(df)   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_1(x_sd = 0))   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_1(error_sd = 0))   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_1(x_mean = 0, x_sd = 0))

what: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
text: Data sets Type 3 get outliers conserving $x$ mean coefficients -different significance- adjusted linear model.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
code: sim_quasianscombe_set_3(   df,   prop = 0.05,   beta1_factor = 0.5,   residual_factor = 0.25 )

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
text: df data frame sim_quasianscombe_set_1 (similar). prop proportion value modify outliers. beta1_factor Numeric value modify beta1 value. residual_factor Numeric value multiply residual modify variance.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
text: function : Calculate linear regression model calculate new trend using 0.5 times beta1 Take prop% values greater 2*prop x values modify related y value get original estimation beta1 Apply residual_factor factor residual get minor variance better visual impresion outlier effect.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 3 — sim_quasianscombe_set_3
code: df <- sim_quasianscombe_set_1()  dataset3 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_3(df)  dataset3 #> # A tibble: 100 × 2 #>        x     y #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  2.86  4.65 #>  2  2.96  4.95 #>  3  3.07  4.88 #>  4  3.19  5.18 #>  5  3.20  5.07 #>  6  3.28  4.97 #>  7  3.34  4.96 #>  8  3.38  5.06 #>  9  3.60  5.00 #> 10  3.61  5.04 #> # … with 90 more rows  plot(dataset3)   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_3(df, prop = 0.1, residual_factor = 0))

what: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
text: Data sets Type 4 recreate two cluster keeping coefficient original regression model.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
code: sim_quasianscombe_set_4(df, rescale_to = c(0.1, 0.2), prop = 0.15)

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
text: df data frame sim_quasianscombe_set_1 (similar). rescale_to Rescale x value create second cluster. prop proportion value modify second group/cluster.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
text: function : Disorder order x values. Rescale x value specific original quantiles. take porportion value traslate left keeppping original mean x. Finally add value associated y value substract complement group regression model term coefficients.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 4 — sim_quasianscombe_set_4
code: df <- sim_quasianscombe_set_1()  dataset4 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_4(df)  dataset4 #> # A tibble: 100 × 2 #>        x     y #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  3.85  5.47 #>  2  3.87  5.44 #>  3  3.88  4.58 #>  4  3.89  5.75 #>  5  3.89  5.69 #>  6  3.94  5.37 #>  7  3.95  4.19 #>  8  3.96  4.70 #>  9  3.96  5.01 #> 10  3.96  4.22 #> # … with 90 more rows  plot(dataset4)   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_4(df, rescale_to = c(0, .1), prop = 0.5))

what: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
text: Data sets Type 5 recreates phenomenon heteroskedasticity residuals.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
code: sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = identity)

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
text: df data frame sim_quasianscombe_set_1 (similar). fun function apply index multiply residuals original model.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
text: function take residuals $e_i$ get $e'_i = e_i * fun()$ rescale $e'_i$ range $e_i$.

title: Generate quasi Anscombe data sets Type 5 — sim_quasianscombe_set_5
code: df <- sim_quasianscombe_set_1()  dataset5 <- sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df)  dataset5 #> # A tibble: 100 × 2 #>        x     y #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1  2.90  4.78 #>  2  3.01  4.82 #>  3  3.26  4.90 #>  4  3.32  4.94 #>  5  3.38  4.97 #>  6  3.46  4.96 #>  7  3.53  5.01 #>  8  3.70  5.09 #>  9  3.76  5.12 #> 10  3.76  5.10 #> # … with 90 more rows  plot(dataset5)   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = rev))   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = sqrt))   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = log))   plot(sim_quasianscombe_set_5(df, fun = function(x) x^(1+0.6)))
